The only drawback is the taste. Unpleasant. But there are ways to get around that:  1. Use only 8 ounces of water, the minimum recommended amount.  2. Make the water as cold as possible - ice water, or at least refrigerated in advance. The colder the water, the less you taste the potion.  3. Have a second beverage to cleanse your taste buds ready to go for right after you drink it.  4. Chug the 8 ounces, and stop drinking as soon as you hit the foam; that's the worst-tasting part.  5. As soon as you have downed it all, grab that taste bud cleanser and take a swig of it. For me, black coffee does the trick.  Bottom line: a superior supplement formula, that actually makes a difference in your energy level. Just be ready to cope with the taste. As a former marathon runner, nutrition has always been important to me. With age comes the need to maintain muscle mass, stamina and working through minor injuries. Nutriceuticals have enhanced my wellness, but taking 15-20 vitamins a day was not very convenient - especially when traveling!   When I researched AG, I was skeptical at first....Read MoreRead more about review stating Skeptical at first . . . I read all of their ingredients, but what sold me was the money back guarantee. Yes, the product is expensive, but the results I noticed - even after a few days, were undeniable!   I no longer take 'extra vitamin B' as I have the sustaining energy throughout the day. It's also nice to have both pre- and probiotics in one easy shaker bottle. The value and convenience are worth it; I just 'budget' accordingly.   As far as the taste, I have to say it tastes good to me. I use 12 oz of water when I mix my drink. Initially I used 8 oz and it seemed too strong. I love the idea behind Athletic Greens, there is no way I could eat the amount of fruit and vegetables needed to get all of the micronutrients contained in the product. That said I question whether the dosages are of any clinical effectiveness as there is very little transparency in the amounts of the ingredients contained in each complex. For exa...Read MoreRead more about review stating Dosage Effectivenessmple the "Digestive Enzyme and Super Mushroom Complex" list the quantity for the total amount of ingredients but doesn't include specifics per ingredient. The total amount of ingredients for the complex is 154mg but depending on the study, the clinically effective dose of reishi is 6 to 12 g extract daily. Ganopoly (a Ganoderma lucidum polysaccharide extract) in doses up to 5.4 g daily (equivalent to 81 g of the fruiting body) for 12 weeks has been used in a few clinical trials.* The entire complex is no where near that dose and reishi specifically is the second to last ingredient listed so I can only assume there is barely a fraction of the effective dose. This leaves one to wonder how Athletic Greens determined the quantity of each ingredient to include, and was it based on any science regarding clinical effectiveness, or is it all marketing to just be able to say they include these really powerful ingredients regardless of effectiveness? I like to think I'm benefitting from Athletic Greens, but considering that I don't really feel any different when I take it, do I just need to double my dose, or considering the miniscule amounts of some of the ingredients would it not even matter and have I been sold on marketing hype alone? I'd love to see more transparency in the quantities of each ingredient as well as support for the dosages they included, otherwise for the nutrients they do quantify, I can get a comparable multivitamin for fraction of the cost.  *https://www.drugs.com/npp/reishi-mushroom.html Read LessRead less about review stating Dosage Effectiveness

For my initial order, I used a coupon code for 5 free singles, and somehow only got 2 in my package. That was a little weird.   Then, after my first order I received a referral link to give out to give people 5 free singles, and told EVERYONE about it, and after I gave out the link I realized that you're REQUIRED to buy a full bag to get those singles. Now, I was willing to lay out the money to try this, but 75-100 is a LOT to expect someone to lay out when trying something new. I thought the whole point of the singles were to get people to see how good the product was, and THEN go buy the monthly supply. That would make more sense, and would probably get you all a lot more orders. I have friends who would be willing to try it for free first, but not lay out the money. column4: Flavor reminds me of a pineapple coconut Bai water
column5: Just started drinking these this morning, but wanted share the flavor profile of the drink for those sensitive to taste since I only saw people describing it as good or bad. Especially since that's what had me on the edge -- I didn't want to spend $100 for stuff that I'd have to choke-down everyday.   Please forgive the pretentious breakdo...Read MoreRead more about review stating Flavor reminds me of a pineapple coconut Bai waterwn... but again, just for people sensitive to taste or REALLY want to avoid something in particular (looking at you stevia).   - First two notes read as pineapple and coconut to me. Pineapple has always hidden bitterness from greens really well in my experience, which I'm imagining is why they picked it. But really hoping the flavor doesn't quickly get old. - No bitterness from the greens, but there is a slightly sweet w/ detectable amounts of stevia (very subtle). - Has a mildly chalky-nutty aftertaste which increases the longer it sits.  - It also went from 0/10 grittiness to maybe a 2/10 grittiness after sitting for 10ish mins.   Overall - definitely palatable and note detoured by taste alone. I don't imagine that I'll be looking forward to drinking it everyday, but I won't dread it either, and definitely didn't have to chug it to finish it. Will for sure continue to buy if the results are there.    GL everyone! Read LessRead less about review stating Flavor reminds me of a pineapple coconut Bai water

column5: Starting around October 2019 to this review today on January 1, 2021, I believe I have the experience to write an honest review of my opinion of Athletic Greens. I'd average four to six Colds per year, each one lasting around four weeks with ten to twelve symptoms from sore...Read MoreRead more about review stating Do Not Want To Live Without throat to sinus triggers to lack of energy to stuffed up and of course miserable each time. I have been using Athletic Greens for 2 months every day. Here are my thoughts:  Pros:  1. I like the formulation of the product and being able to take my vitamins in a non-pill form. I see studies around the effectiveness of pill vitamins and it doesn't seem good. Many of them have fillers and the active ingredients may not be abs...Read MoreRead more about review stating Good not greatorbed as effectively compared to other forms (natural food source being best, but it's not always concentrated enough to be efficient)  2. I feel healthy on the product. I can't point to one specific example of an improvement like others have, it's just more a general sense of well-being on the nutrition front. How much is related to this product vs my generally good diet is hard to tell, but I feel the product is a benefit.  Cons:  1. Expensive. Did I say expensive? I don't like that they charge $8 shipping on top of an already expensive product. Add in tax and it's costing over $90 per bag which I believe is too expensive. I believe they should reduce or eliminate the shipping cost.  2. Absorption. I find this product hard to dissolve completely. I use a shaker and it mostly dissolves but I still find undissolved residue at the bottom. For me it can be hard to swallow the last portion of the bottle and I usually just leave it untouched. It has a fine sand consistency that doesn't go down easily. On the positive side I find the taste of the product decent and at least 90% of it feels like it dissolves and is easy to drink down.  3. Disposable plastic: Every bag comes with a plastic scoop. I think this should be eliminated. First of all it's wasteful, secondly it's not helpful: the handle is short and when the contents get low you end up with a lot of green dust on your hands. It is better to use a reusable long handled measuring spoon. Everyone has or can get one of these for a few dollars. Please echo my call for the company to stop shipping disposable plastic scoops. I get asked about it almost daily at the hospital and I promote it to everyone I know. Favorite feature is the promotion of gut health. The protective lining in our stomach is approximately half the size of a strand of hair, and we must do whatever it takes to protect it. Without that protection, we can develop ulcers or even leaky gut. Leaky gut ...Read MoreRead more about review stating Love it!is a relatively new concept in medicine and we are finding that makes us susceptible to cancers and degenerative diseases. So I highly recommend athletic greens for gut health. I also highly recommend eating fermented foods as that is the best probiotic for the gut.   I also like to recommend athletic greens because of the organic ingredients. That means no GMO's, herbicides, pesticides, or harmful chemicals. Organic is what our bodies need. Non-organic food is treated with glyphosate (Roundup) which is proven to break down the lining of the stomach (Bad for gut health). Glyphosate is then able to enter our bloodstream via the stomach and pass through the blood brain barrier. Very harmful to the body. So eat and drink organic. Due to weight training, having my own physical therapy small business, and being the father of 5 kids, it was always fairly easy for me to maintain a lean 6‚Äô1‚Äù, 195 lbs. That certainly changed when I was diagnosed with a rare and aggressive, stage 4 gallbladder and liver cancer In January of 2020. I suddenly felt terrible, then began heavy chemoth...Read MoreRead more about review stating RightIng a Sinking The Ship!erapy, felt worse, and my body weight plummeted to a low of 155 around mid March. For years I tinkered with various greens mixes, but all of them tasted terrible and were not worth the cost or time of having them. Besides, I took pride in taking no supplements or medications, getting everything my body would need through a healthy, well...fairly healthy diet. I never needed to lose weight, had a great health profile, and so didn‚Äôt think much more about any of that. Now I suspect that some of my micronutrients along with omega-3 fatty acids had been deficient for years.   Anyway, I began taking athletic greens in mid March 2020, in a bit of a desperate place. I was frail and felt terrible. The athletic greens tasted fine to my fickle chemotherapy tastes, and I would often alternate drinking this and high calorie protein shakes, each twice per day, when I was nauseous and couldn‚Äôt keep much normal food down. I started weight training again; short, basic movements with a small fraction of the loading that I would be able to handle prior to this diagnosis.   Somehow, I started coming out of it. The ship was at least heading in the right direction. Even DURING my ongoing heavy chemotherapy regimen, my blood profiles have been slowly improving, my CT scans have shown cancer regression (though I still have some digging out to do), my body weight is slowly climbing (currently a little over 170 lbs), and my strength is greatly improved.   It would be wrong for me to claim that AG treats or cures cancer. But I seriously suspect it as one of a few critical factors in my recovery thus far. I‚Äôm now actually optimistic regarding my short term prognosis, though it can be a grind. The mid-term is currently uncertain as chemotherapy is not a long term solution to my situation. The long term is still plain frightening. But I know that I will continue with AG, and it is well worth the cost and time to help me recover to the greatest extent possible.   Photos- I don‚Äôt have many of myself. 1-kayaking with one of my daughters last summer. 2-farmer walk with 400 lb for 80 yards on my 41st birthday. So, I'm definitely not a doctor or scientist, and this is only my anecdotal data, but I feel that I have to share my experience. I'm 59 years old, and had a full thyroidectomy a little more than 5 years ago. I am not an athlete, but I walk 5-7 miles/day, eat clean, and do resistance training every day. I have never been able to recapture the same ...Read MoreRead more about review stating Amazing energy hitenergy levels as I enjoyed pre-cancer. Perhaps 80-85% as a baseline. Before my cancer, my numbers were always good, as I follow a whole food, plant-based diet. In fact, the OR staff expressed amazement at them for a then 54-year old. Surgery went great, and after a year of dialing in the meds, the aforementioned energy levels seemed the best I could do. I long ago accepted this, counting my blessing that I'm still alive and generally feel pretty good.  Recently, my daughter -- a well-conditioned athlete -- gave me a travel pack of Athletic Greens to try. She is a huge advocate of the product. Stopped drinking coffee, eats less during the day, etc. I kid you not, but after drinking just a few sips, I could feel a tingling throughout my body -- like I had just taken a hit of something very pleasant and very illegal. My body just immediately responded. I finished the drink and just flew though the day, feeling great. I took it at around 7:00 am, and wasn't hungry until late afternoon. But more importantly, I feel more energy --real energy as opposed to a caffeine buzz -- all day. Until I went to bed. I was sharp and focused; I hadn't felt that way since before my surgery. I know use it every day, and never feel the need for breakfast (which probably pays for the AG subscription in itself). It's been a life-changer for me. I wish it didn't have Stevia, but I cannot deny the salutary effects it bestows. We're all different, with different body chemistries and nutritional profiles, but I have to recommend it highly. It's certainly a no-brainer worth trying if you know someone who can hook you up. If you have to pay for a single pouch, I know it's a lot, but you're covered by a 60-day guarantee.
